With the growth this village sees it may well one day become a small town, lying on the Hochland border and on the main road just shy of the town of grimmigen has seen may pass through on their way to the capital, or towards either Hochland or Reikland. A lot of its current growth is owed to how well situated it is, as well as its Town Council that, rather uniquely, runs it in place of a lord.

This castle stands vigil along the Great Northern Road to and from the Wastelands, the garrison that patrols its walls often watch a wide range of traders, travellers. Pilgrims and more pass by on their way to and from the Capital. More importantly it safeguards against a tribe of forest goblins that have made the surrounding Drakwald their home.

This village has seen its share of tragedy, it is unclear when it first occured but a tribe of forest goblins have plagued this village for many years and despite the many patrols from the nearby castle for Dajnst, many still fall pray to these creatures of the Drakwald.

Further along the Great Northern Road, this village sees far less of the greenskin threat that plagues the surrounding villages, it is far more common to meet travellers and hear stories from the many who pass by on their way to the Capital, or who are returning to the Wastelands.

Ever since the destruction of Mordheim, Biechafien has served as the provincial capital of Ostermark. Its buildings are tall and thin and are made of dark wood from the Great Forest, particularly the Gryphon Wood, which gives the buildings an eerie look to them. Although the wood from the Great Forest is unsavoury in colour, its hardy and makes a perfect material for many industries. Biechafien is particularly known for its exceptional boatyards and the well-crafted river vessels hailing from here. The dwarf king of Karak-Kadrin gifted Biechafien a pair of water-powered sawmills, allowing for the logs that are shipped downriver to the city to be turned into more easily transportable, and readily used, planks.

Dorna plays an important role in collecting revenue from passing ships and harvesting trees in the south as well as serving as a resting area for sailors, before they and their bundles of timber continue with their journey south towards talabheim or beyond.

Lying close to the mouth of the river Brunwasser makes the villagers of Miunkienchof quite adept at fishing, supplying food for Biechafien and for the surrounding villages in times of need. The sturdy Fishing boats have defended their owner many times from would-be predators who try to push them out of their boat or capsize them entirely, only to end up with a bump on the head and a harpoon between the eyes.
Being so close to the river Brunwasser provides the village of Rajtvajn with rich soil on which they grow their flax
Ruhienbuttł

Along the road to the west lies Ruhienbuttł, an unassuming forest village. Despite seeing moderate traffic pass through, the village itself is very poor, it might be that travellers prefer to get out of the dark forest as fast as possible and prefer to move on to the safety of places like Biechafien.

Ajzental acts as an important trading hub between Ostermark and the dwarfs of Karak Kadrin. Due to its position along the River Blut and being the first stop for dwarfen traders, its waterways and nearby roads are typically well guarded, all but a large orc horde being easily handled by Ajzentals troops.
Miłaŭ

At the junction of the river Aurith and the Upper Blut lies Miłaŭ, an unassuming village of sheepherders. Its remote location allows them plenty of grazing space for their livestock and ensures they grow big and fat and produce high-quality wool.
Where the Upper and Lower Blut combines into the Blut River, lies Bissendorf. Bissendorf uses its access to the Blut to timber the Blut Wood, which grows between the Upper and Lower Bluts
Taŭer

At the southern end of the Ostermark Marches lies Taŭer. The foothills near Taŭer are fertile but rugged, allowing the people here great harvests with some effort. Thanks to this, the people here are hardy and strong but remain poor.

Along the Kadrin road lies Nahienchof, an imposing fortress city which guards the eastern foothills of Ostermark from Greenskin incursions. Nahienchof rarely sees any real threat of invasion however, this is accredited to the many slayer throngs which pass through the town, heading east to find their doom.

The herders of Bukov often trespass across the river to feed their sheep as close to the veldt as possible, much to Margrave Konrad Röntgens dismay. He can never catch them in the act to do something about it either, but those sheep dont get fat from eating the scarce bits of grass that grow in the foothills.

The final stop when one heads east and usually the first when one comes from it. Vajler is a wealthy enough village as villages go due to the amount of traffic it sees, both from traders and passing slayers, spending their last bit of coin before seeking their end in battle.

On one hand an imposing city, where tradesmen ply their craft and the markets are bustling with people, the sounds of hammers and the murmuring of people filling the streets. On the other, near the river, the banks are lined with docks and fishing boats, fishermen from all across Ostermark come here to provide for their families. Remier exports vast quantities of fish to various towns and villages within the league.
Cajšolc

A modest village consisting of mainly shepherds. Great swathes of land to the east are reserved for the many cows the village owns. Preferring to avoid conflict with Margrave Konrad Röntgen, theyve fenced off the border of the veldt to the east so their cows wont wander into the veldt by accident.

Cheffienhien, locally known for breeding fast and sturdy horses. The people of Cheffienhien are proud and utilise their living space very well to accommodate their many crafts. It is therefore a great annoyance that they hold little authority over the veldt, where they could expand their animal husbandry substantially.

Along the Biechafien road lies Elbinh, Elbinh sees a decent amount of traffic, being the last stop for a while if one heads east, or the first stop if one comes from it. The villagers are well fed, the inn is usually bustling and any undead that wanders in from the bleak moors is usually dealt with swiftly.

With the Dead wood lying in the west, the Eerie downs in the east and Hel fen to the south. It is often speculated that the dead walk with the living and ghosts roam the streets as often as any living man. The reality is much more grim, the town is under constant threat of being attacked by the undead or a stray chaos creature that wanders too far from the dead wood. The commoners living in Essen live out their meagre lives behind the walls while the militia, well versed in the culling of the undead, are constantly on patrol to preserve the lives of their loved ones.
Karłsbruk

Being an important source of food to Essen, many patrols come through here regularly to deal with the undead from the eirie downs and the odd horde that slips through from the southwest. The villagers of Karłsbruk constantly seek to expand their farmlands, the soil is barren and barely anything grows, and what little grows goes straight to Essen. It doesnt help that the undead corruption spreads so rapidly and claims more and more farmland.

An important strategic position both for protection against invasions and collecting revenues from crossing the river. Being so close to the northern border it is no surprise that many of Fortenchafs inhabitants are from Kislev, relations between the Imperials and the Kislevites are often cold at best, and many tavern brawls are broken up around nighttime. However, they both know one thing, if their home is threatened, they will stand shoulder to shoulder to defend it till their dying breath.

A large swathe of the Gryphon Wood surrounds Hierduen, every day men go out to cut as much timber as they can so it can be floated downriver to Biechafien. With the amount of wood taken, its a surprise the treeline never seems to shrink

The green grass, wide fields and clean water of Ryden make it an ideal place to herd sheep and settle down. The area is a known crossing for forest goblins, seeking to forge their way across the Upper Talebec and into the Empire. Usually, the shepherds can deal with these savages but their numbers occasionally swell, resulting in the village seeking aid to deal with their infestation.

As the provincial capital of Hochland, Chierhih is a bustling hub nestled in the dense Drakwald Forest. Known for its masterful woodcraft and the iconic Hochland College of Sorcery, the city is a blend of sturdy woodland architecture and sophisticated fortifications. The streets are often filled with the sounds of craftsmen at work and the occasional marching of soldiers, reflecting Chierhihs strategic importance and cultural richness. The towns architecture, traditionally of stone and brick, reflects its more modern aspirations, partly driven by the skillful contributions of its Dwarf Quarter. The Gate of the East bridge, a site of historical battles between Ostland and Hochland, marks its strategic importance to the city. Despite suffering greatly in the war, including a devastating siege that led to the fall of the great keep, Chierhih is in a phase of rebirth.
Dunšcihfurt

Dunšcihfurt, nestled along the River Talabec, is a small village known for its excellent fishing and timber houses. The villagers, adept in using the rivers resources, provide fresh fish to nearby towns, including Chierhih. The surrounding woods, like many other villages in Hochland, offer a relatively serene backdrop.

Miuden is a village located at the base of the river Kiefer. Its proximity to the mountains allows for a thriving mining community, extracting valuable minerals. The rugged landscape surrounding Miuden provides a natural defense, and its people are known for their resilience.
Štoks

Štoks, a small village located on a river end opposite of Miuden, is renowned for its skilled hunters and trappers, even for your average Hochlander. The dense forest provides ample game, and the villagers are known for their expertise in navigating and surviving in the challenging woodland terrain.

Breder is a significant Hochlander city located along the foothills of the Middle Mountains. Known for much of the city being built underground, in the foothills of the Middle Mountains. Known for its well-maintained walls, it serves as a key trading post for goods coming from the Middle Mountains and the Drakwald Forest. The city has a diverse population, a melting pot of dwarfs and native Hochlanders.

Esk is a small mining and logging village situated in the foothills of the Middle Mountains. The village is known for its hard working miners and lumbermen, who provide essential resources to the larger settlements in Hochland.

Tucked away along the foothills of the Middle Mountains just like its sister village Esk, Kioryn is a small village known for its skilled miners and artisans. The villagers expertly craft items from stone and ores extracted from the mountains that reside nearby it.

As the second-largest settlement in Hochland, Krudenvald is a city marked by its history of resilience and hospitality. Its a hub for adventurers and mercenaries, offering a mix of rugged wilderness and urban amenities. The citys population is diverse, including a significant number of Dwarf Slayers, sellswords and other transient warriors.
Harssen, a small village in eastern Hochland, is known for its agriculture along with its ordinary timber production. The villages location between two rivers.

Set against the Middle Mountains, at the mouth of one of them any streams that flows into the great River Talabec lies this small village. Its people live ominously close to the Brass Keep and its presence can be felt even from such a distance, despite this they do their best to live in hope that the threat of Chaos will never come.
Farteca Korv

Just to the west of this castle stands the mighty Talabheim, just across the River Talabec. Much of the trade ships that sail the river can be seen from the castle walls, and the garrison is often called to patrol its shores.
Štrudel

One of the few villages along the River Talabec to not be encroached upon by the mighty pine forests commonly found within the Empire, its proximity to the major river has all manner of folk pass by this otherwise unassuming village.
Farteca Šyppiel

A lonely bastion overlooking the treacherous fens and hill country known as the Weiss Hills, its walls have seen and survived various sieges but stand resolute nontheless. Its garrison numbers have lessened over the years but its no less able to safeguard its surroundings.

A small shrine village dedicated to the worship of the Imperial Pantheons many gods, it sits on the river Talabec and looks to the local garrison in Fort Korver for its protection, and for that of its few pilgrims. It is also known as the home of the one hundred year old seer of Hrujden, whom many seek.

Nestled within the forests amidst the Weiss hills, Barwedal has seen spouts of misfortune. From missing villagers to savage raiders, yet the quiet life of the village continues out of sheer stubbornness.
Farteca Dench

Resting against the river Drakwasser and bordering Middenland, this fort oversees a myriad of surrounding villages in the hopes of safeguarding them, as there are many threats lurking within the forests and hills of Hochland.

Found near one of the many tendrils that flow from the River Talabec, and the Drakwasser, this humble village is just one of many to be found across Hochland filled with hardy folk eeking out a meagre living under Sigmars watchful gaze.

Zalcenmund, the capital city of the Imperial Electoral Province of Nordland and a principality of the Empire in its own right, rests among hills from which flow the tributaries that join to form the River Salz, from which the city gets its name. The Elector Counts built tall castles at the top of these hills overlooking the growing city, once the meeting place for the western scions of the Was Jutone tribe. So narrow is the approach to the keep named the Jutones Nest that it needs no surrounding curtain wall: the great keep just sits there, watching over the region. It is said by the locals that the Elector Counts can see the whole of his province from the window of his throne room, which faces west so he can keep an eye on the Elves of Laurelorn Forest.

Biekierchoven is a busy trading town in Nordland in the Empire. It is known as the Gateway to Nordland and is located along the Middenchajm-Erengrad road. The surrounding woods are renowned for heavy, naturally crooked branches which can be cut and used for the curved parts of ships which ensures it is in high demand.

It has been used as a meeting place between the Empire and the Eonir using a grassy amphitheatre outside the town.Timber is floated downriver to be sold in Zalcenmund and barges also take agricultural goods, silver and lead

Kurtvallen is a village of hunters and trappers located 64km north of Zalcenmund, in a forest region far from any other town. Two hundred years ago, during the last Chaos Incursion, this region was infested with monstrosities and abominations beyond imagination. Among all the hordes of Chaos was a band of Werewolves. They were thrown back into the forest and then exterminated by the White Wolf Templars. After decades of tranquility, hunters and trapp. Although the village does not have an inn, travelers can stay in the granary above the stables. Anyone who insists on spending the night outside will constantly see shadows coming and going and hear the yips of local wolves some distance away.

Dziterschafen is a coastal city in Nordland and current seat of the Second Fleet of the Imperial Navy. Dziterschafen is the Empires most important coastal seaport. Its shipyards bustle with activity as shipwrights build new vessels for the Second Fleet. The celebrated Dziterschafen Harbour Guard patrol and drill on the waterfront. Victuallers haggle for mountains of salt-dried stockfish, vast quantities of small beer, and crates of ships biscuits. Overseeing all of this is Baron Ludolf Köhler, who hopes to build a fleet surpassing that of Bretonnia or Maryjenburh. The town is thriving. A steady stream of timber flows into the city and merchants make fat profits from free-spending sailors. Dwarf artisans work at considerable expense to improve the town walls -- historically a weak point in the ports defences. If you can use a hammer, sail a boat, or fight, you can find work in Dziterschafen.

Luftbierh is a village located a days ride north of Salzenburg on the Nordland coast. There was a church of Ulric in the village. After an attack, which was probably carried out by high elves, the church no longer existed, but an obelisk stood in the same place that consumed anyone who touched it in blue fire. Most villagers are farmers and lumberjacks.
Noje Emskrank

Neues Emskrank was the first port in Nordland to open in 2460 IC as a scheme to siphon off business from Maryjenburh. Failed miserably. Originally a small fishing village called Pugsblatter, the rights to the town were bought by an investment group headed by a charlatan named Jens-Pieter Riemanns, and which numbered among its backers three Elector Counts and several lesser but still wealthy and powerful nobles and Imperial merchant houses. Their plan was to create two ports that would siphon off traffic from Maryjenburh, thus cutting out the middlemen there and creating more profits for themselves. To this end, Pugsblatter was bought in 2460 and renamed Neues Emskrank. The local residents were forced out and resettled in the area of Vilhielmskuh, and colonists were brought in to reinvigorate the place. The cartel built houses and shops to give the city a fresh look, they invested in warehouses to handle the traffic surely coming their way, and they built new trading caravels that would be the vanguard of their fleet. Naturally, it was a total disaster.

Chajlihdorf is a religious village dedicated to Manaan. Most of the inhabitants work as fisherman or are in the imperial navy. The village Is one of the biggest supporters of the Nordland mariners giving them many sons to fight.

Located at the eastern extreme of the Drosselspule Bay, Nordland, in truth Norden is secretly being developed as base of operations for exploration and conquest of Lustria. It is also used in transporting prisoners to Leopoldheim in the Southlands. Norden has an advantage over other ports, in that its located close to the Middenchajm-Erengrad road, a major thoroughfare for trade and other travel. Until recently, it was an open town where merchants from Middenchajm, Nordland, and western Ostland traded goods with ports around the Sea of Claws using large flat vessels suited to the shallow sandy channels around Norden. But the town is no longer open to outsiders. Carts and wagons are turned away several miles from Norden by halberdiers from the State Army. A trading post at the Mananns Crown coaching inn in Zalcmorast allows merchants to trade without getting close to the town.

Biilen is a Big town along the Middenchajm-Erengrad road. Biilen may not directly benefit economically from its location, it certainly has avoided threats of Norse raiders for years, with Kreideklipper and Zalcmorast providing more lucrative targets. The town of Norden, its fortifications and small fleet, are a deterrent to coastal raids. Not to mention the natural geography of the coastline being difficult to navigate. They main trade is grain and wool.

Hielcinh is a trade post on the Middenchajm-Erengrad road it mainly sells the fish caught by the fishers of kreideklippe, To merchant caravans on the road. It also has a pleasure house The humming mermaid, Most sailors spend their hard earned coin in the pleasure house.

Krajdeklippe is a Fishing village with quite a large fishing fleet. Most people born in Krajdeklippe either Work as fisherman or as fish trader. Because of the position of Krajdeklippe they are often victim of raids by norscans.
Zalcmorast Famous for its Mannans crown coaching inn. It is a large trading post. Zalcmorast territory is a swampy one with salt water.

Charhiendorf is a sizable fishing town of Nordland in the Empire, located west of the port city of Dziterschafen. It is the home of the Imperial Navys Second Fleet. It also has the dubious honour of being the birth village of Archaon in 2390 IC.Charhiendorf is some distance from the main settlements of Nordland, located on the east bank of the River Demst. Its a busy port, where ships stop for provisions and trade vessels buy salt, fish, sheep, and wool. Given its remote location, not much trade offloads at Charhiendorf, which makes it ideal for more illicit business.
Šłahchiuhel

Manannsheim is an Imperial fort situated on a small island in the Drosselspule Bay of Nordland. It is also home to the Monastery of the Order of the Triton. The fort is heavily armed with canons and trained Nordland mariners.

Vilhielmskuh is a big town with a pilot guild called Manaans eye. The pilots are experts in sailing the Sea of claws and are always onboard of imperial navy vessels. The pilots make sure tradingvessels get safe into the harbour of Noje Emskrank making sure that the flow of trade doesnt get hindered. Due to the expertise of the pilots the local fisherman are well informed of the spots with the highest quality of fish.

Volfienburh is the capital of the Grand Principality of Ostland, and Ostlands largest settlement. Nestled in the foothills of the Middle Mountains, it is a beautiful city, and lies at the crossroads of trade moving overland between Kislev and the Empire. Its great walls provide protection from the evil things that lurk within the Forest of Shadows. The von Raukovs, who rule Ostland from Volfienburh, have brought order and stability to the province after a succession of inept and suspect rulers.
Hrunakieren is a small town south of Volfienburh on the road to Vurcen, and is therefore often the final stop for traffic approaching Ostlands capital from the provinces key riverport on the Talabec.

Due north of Volfienburh on the road to Fierłanhien, and thence Zalkalten, Mielbek is a small village of little note beyond its inns catering for travellers. An ancient and abandoned Dwarfen mine is said to be located somewhere west of Mielbek in the Middle Mountains.
Ryšted
The mining village of Ryšted lies at the confluence of the River Eiskalt and the Wolfs Run, a short way east of Castle Łenkster.
Smołłchof

Vurcen is a town (sizeable, by Ostland standards) on the north bank of the Talabec River. It is a key riverport for the province, and profits from the lively trade along the Talabecs eastern stretches. It is also one of the major ferry crossings between Ostland and Talabecland to the south.
Čenhier
Čenhier is a small agricultural village close to Vurcen, its arable surrounding farmland well irrigated by the River Talabec.
Daroh is a small cattle ranching settlement not far northwest of Vurcen, close to the Boven Road.
Fierłanhien

Fierłanhien is an important market town in central Ostland, and a staging post on the route between Volfienburh in the south and the northern coastal port of Zalkalten. Its hereditary rulers are the Beckburg family. It is known nationwide as the home of its famous regiment of handgunners, the Fireloques of Fierłanhien.
Aŭkruh
A poor hamlet south of Fierłanhien, Aŭkruh is de facto run by the Trautsun family, the proprietors of the settlements largest inn and carriage station.
Dunkielpfad is a small mining village due south of Öbelstein. Lead, quartz, and silver are extracted from the Middle Mountains by the surrounding mines.

Zalkalten is one of two towns founded in a failed attempt to draw trade away from Maryjenburh (the other being Neues Emskrank in Nordland). Grand Prince Ivan von Königswald poured money into expanding Salkaltens harbour and beautifying the buildings in 2455 IC. When the promised influx of trade failed to appear, Zalkalten returned to its previous indolence and the towns people, with typical Ostlander thriftiness, tore up much of the decorative façade and statues to repurpose. Zalkalten maintains logging camps in the Forest of Shadows, and most of its industry today is in lumber and fishing, though it remains Ostlands key seaport. It is noteworthy as the home of the Sons of Manann knightly order.
Fierborhienbucht is a fishing village east of Zalkalten along the coast of the Sea of Claws.

Bochzenfiels, also known as Little Middenchajm, is a fortress-city located in the outer march of Ostland. It is built upon large rocks with caves and tunnels dug underneath, forming a subterranean labyrinth that allows the fortress to maintain enough supplies to hold out against a long siege.
Fohielzanh is a small farming village northwest of Bochzenfiels. It is the hereditary seat of House Hohenzollern.
Zamak Łenkster

Zamak Łenkster is a fort overlooking a border crossing that leads through the Middle Mountains to Hochland. It is said that the mountains where it stands were once cursed by the last Dwarf priests of Karaz Ghumzul. It maintains a permanent garrison of Ostlander border guards.
The castle-town of Hrencburh is the monastic home of the Sigmarite cult of the Purging Hammer. It guards one of Ostlands main southern roads into Kislev.
Vandenhart is a small town west of Hrencburh, along the Volfienburh Road. Its primary industries are trade and swine farming. It is the hereditary seat of the von Seeckt family.
Kurst is a village within the Forest of Shadows, north of the Volfienburh-Hrencburh Road.

The castle-town of Roezfels guards the western passes from Ostland through the Middle Mountains to Hochland. It has long been ruled by the staunchly traditionalist Margraves of the von Döbreiner noble house.
Obielštajn
Hereditary seat of House von Öbelstein, Öbelstein is primarily a centre of lumber milling. It lies between Roezfels to the west and Fierłanhien to the northeast.
Masianžavaje Trymańnie

The Brass Keep is a very old fortress, indeed its older than Sigmar himself. No one knows who built it, only that it has changed owners many times, until recently. During the Great War Against Chaos, the fortress was besieged by many Chaos warlords, many pledging their loyalty to Khorne, Slaanesh, Tzeentch, and Nurgle. While it was under siege, the followers of Nurgle corrupted the foundations, fermenting a plague within the fortress. The chaos forces would eventually succeed in taking the fortress, but were then cut off from reinforcements, sealing their doom within. The only survivors of such a glorious plague were the Nurgle devotees themselves, who now bask in the repugnant citadel.
Vieža Mielchiora

Hidden in the forest of Shadows lies the tower of the Necrach Melkhior the Ancient, After loosing the battle with his former student Zacharias the Everliving the tower was destoyed. After claiming the tower for himself Zacharias decided to rebuild the tower and use it for his study of the Grimoire Necronium.
Tor Litanel

Tor Litanel is the capital city of the Wood Elf realm of the Eonir, located in the Ward of the Sun, at the centre of the Laurelorn Forest. The capital of the Laurelorn Forest is a rare surviving example of archaic High Elven architecture. Within the city walls, exotic fruit and nut trees are cultivated with the aid of magic. The huge gems adorning nearly every building contain souls of deceased Elves, held permanently in stasis to preserve them from consumption by Chaos. From a distance, these soul-gems catch the light and cause the city to glisten. Humans who have approached close enough to witness Tor Litanels splendour have nicknamed it the City of Glass
Iścin Vauł Mienłuit Kajš

Iścin Vauł Mienłuit Kajš, also known by mortals as the Rainbow Falls is a small elven hamlet on the border of the Wards of Sun and Frost. Within the waterfall, ruins of stout obelisks of old elven magic had fallen into the crest of the waters, infusing the falls with all 8 winds of magic that coincides with the nearby waystones. Many of Vauls disciples gather underneath the waterfall and use the infused waters, and the wind of Chamon and a weak form of Aqshy to coldforge great works of arms and armors.
Vierdan Litrydrom

A dense plantation of larch and firs and larches sacred to Sarriel, God of Dreams. A dense stand of firs and larches near Tor Litanel is sacred to worshippers of Sarriel, the God of Dreams. Well-trodden paths end abruptly at waystones marking the woods edge. Beyond sagging branches draped with curtains of lichen is a heavy, foreboding darkness. Eonir pilgrims are fearful of the spirits within, preferring instead to meditate for dream-visions at the perimeter. At the centre of the wood is a crumbling, overgrown amphitheatre that predates Elf colonists. The Queen of the Laurelorn knows the forum is actually an Old One portal to distant Avelorn, via an esoteric realm called the ‘Dreaming Wood. The portal is damaged however, making the Dreaming Wood unstable and preventing transit to Avelorn.
Krynica Lebina

Krynica Lebina is a village near Tor Litanel. It is located in a privileged location, since it is located in a huge stone basin that purifies the tainted water of the river beyond the Valley of Despair. These pristine waters make the surrounding land rich and fertile, nourishing crops and trees alike, satisfying the demand of the Eonir population.
Vieža Sie-Acil

Sarrielrien is an Eonir settlement along the path that runs along the laurelorn forest along the coastline. The humid wind that comes from the Sea of Claws creates the ideal environment for the trees to grow stronger and produce larger than usual fruits.
Skała Farysara
Arot Łoren

The Wardens of the Frost live nomadically so they can manage the shared forests and ensure that no Imperials settle east of the Demst River. Despite their wandering nature, it is common to see them in the vicinity of Arot Łoren. This Eonir fortress is their bastion against Nordlands constant efforts to claim this territory for their nation. And also against occasional hordes of Greenskins and Beastmen.
Kor Immarmor

To the East of Tor Litanel, Kor Immarmor was the neighbouring city in the elder days, when the Human tribes were still uttering guttural language. When Malekith the Deceiver began the War of Vengeance, also known as the War of the Beard to the Elves, Kor Immarmor was the first city to fall in Laurelorn. Now decrepit, many Eonir still visit the ruins to pay their respects and to honour the dead that have fallen there.
Łatajn

The excessively humid climate in the south of the Laurelorn forest has created an ideal ecosystem for certain types of trees and plants to germinate that would not exist in these latitudes. The village of Łatajn was founded by the Eonir to benefit from these new resources that the forest offers.

Maryjenburh is one of the greatest human cities in the Old World, and possibly the wealthiest, rivalled only by Altdorf, Erengrad, Miragliano, and the richest cities of Araby. Situated at the point where the River Reik enters the Sea of Claws, Maryjenburh is the only route for maritime trade to efficiently leave or enter the Empire. The city itself sits on a series of islands connected together by bridges and boat travel. To the north and south, the Vloedmuur wall sits just off the coast to defend the city from flooding and attacks by land. The wall is an ancient one, originally built by elves. The modern wall has been built and rebuilt several times atop the old elven foundations and the Directorate - Marienburgs executive council - has spent a great fortune modernising its gates and redoubts. The defence of the city from attacks along the Reik, or from the Manaanspoort Sea, falls on Marienburgs substantial navy. Just a century ago, the Wasteland was one of the jewels of Sigmars empire, but after generations of benign neglect by a series of successive emperors, the merchants and burghers of Maryjenburh declared their independence. Emperor Wilhelm III launched several unsuccessful expeditions against the separatist province, all of which failed, culminating in independence being granted by treaty in 2429. Today, Maryjenburh is ruled by its legislature, the Stadsraad, and its executive council, the Directorate. Under this ‘republican rule, trade has continued to flow through Maryjenburh and many consider the city to be in a golden age. It is protected by its reputation of being nearly ungovernable and its varied mercenary forces, as well as by the River Reik and the marshes and swamps around. Nevertheless, the new Emperor, Karl Franz, may want to accomplish what his great-great-grandfather was unable to do. At the same time, Bretonnian dukes have made attempts in the past to incorporate Maryjenburh into their domains; who knows if King Louen will make an attempt of his own to expand the Marches of Kuronn?
Brojkŭoter

Brojkŭoter is a poor community along the coast of the Manaanspoort sea, consisting mostly of several run down cottages, a smattering of decrypted inns and a handful of fishing huts. It is the only inhabited settlement on the ancient coast road between Maryjenburh and Bretonnia, as such its continued existence is likely only spurred on by traders and travellers. Rumours persist as well that pirates may be using the area as their base of operations, but nothing official has been said or done about them.

Kalkaat is a small town located on the road between the Empire and Maryjenburh. The people here are wastelanders through and through but do feel a certain loyalty to the empire and its gods. In particular the cult of Sigmar has a very long standing, as well as extremely orthodox, temple here.

On the banks of the river Reik as it flows along the border of the Drakwald forest is the small town of Lejdenchovien. The people here are friendly to travellers and in the Maryjenburh fashion will take people into their homes when they need a place to stay. The town mostly subsists on its flocks of sheep, but travellers stopping over from the Empire on their way to Maryjenburh often stay in one of their several riverfront inns
Aarnaŭ

At the end of the Old North road, on the coast of the sea of claws and the Wastelands border with Nordland and Middenland, is the Barony van Buurens, the last noble house of old Westerland. Baron van Buurens will tell anyone that Aarnaŭ and its people are the guardians of the Wasteland, though for many decades no one has been quite sure what exactly they are defending against. The city itself is well fortified, and has seen off many Norscan warbands over the years. The State Troops of Aarnaŭ are well drilled, professional men drawn from soldiers for hire and the local militia. While derisively referred to as the ‘Peacocks due to their resplendent uniforms provided by the Baron, they are fine warriors who have faced down highwaymen, outlaws and worse in the nearby Tumble Downs.
Chołłum

On the coast of the Sea of Claws is the village of Chołłum. It is said that the settlement was once a large town but that many centuries ago a Norscan raid nearly destroyed everything, leaving only a few scattered survivors and ruins. Today, only the locals can speak of this as they ply their trades and bring in fish from the sea.

Situated on the edge of the Tumble Downs is the farming settlement of Charskamp. The people here raise vegetables and grain for sustenance, but also produce sheep and wool for nearby Aarnaŭ and often Maryjenburh.
Farteca Sołas

Farteca Sołas is a fortified lighthouse across the Manaanspoort sea from Reavers point. It is owned and operated by the Wasteland Import-Export exchange in Maryjenburh, who maintain a governor and private garrison here. Fort Sołas is a relatively new settlement, constructed in response to Almshovens abandonment and the destruction of its lighthouse. Most ships will stop here if arriving too late in the evening to make it into Maryjenburh, few will stop here with the intention of bypassing Maryjenburh all together on their way to Norsca or Kislev.

Horssel is a large salt mining settlement owned by the Wasteland Import-Export Exchange in Maryjenburh. All of the people who live here are ‘Change employees. Salt mining is extremely dangerous, as such the men who work in the mines are very haggard, many have burns on their arms from working with the salt. Horssel is one of the only salt mines in the old world to not rely on peasant or slave labour for its production. While the miners here may complain about their pays, they are receiving a relatively handsome one.
Mytnia Voŭduin
Farteca Bierhbres

Farteca Bierhbres demarcates the border between the Wasteland and Bretonnia. As part of a deal between the Duke of Žyzoru and Marienburgs Directorate, the tolling station is operated by both the excise men of the Wasteland and Gisereuxs roadwardens. Both the excise men and the roadwardens are tasked with seeing to the safe flow of trade through the Žyzoru gap and along the Bitter Moors, but they are notorious for inaction unless suitably ‘paid up-front, giving credence to the nickname ‘Fort Beg-Bribe. While the tolling station is neutral ground, the fort itself is just over the border in Marienburgs favour, as such the wealthy city-state has maintained a formidable garrison here.
Erłach

Castle Kuronn stood tall since the time when elves still roamed the lands that are now Bretonnia. Home to the seat of power, its imposing white walls, gleaming in the sunlight, are a testament to the kingdoms enduring strength and the legacy of its noble rulers. Within the fortress lies the revered High Temple of Shallya, where pilgrims and knights alike come to seek the goddesss mercy and healing. Beyond its sacred halls, the castle boasts vast tournament grounds where the bravest of Bretonnias knights compete in displays of martial prowess, honour, and chivalry. Nearby stands the ancient Abbey of the Grail Companions, a solemn place of worship and remembrance where the legends of Bretonnias greatest heroes—those who rode with Gilles le Breton himself—are honoured and preserved. Castle Kuronn has endured many sieges in days past, beset by greenskins, beastmen, Norscan marauders, Skaven, and the undead. It has withstood them all and will continue to do.

Rynness is renowned for breeding strong and fast horses. It is one of the few places where nobles willingly suffer the barnlike stench of horse and peasant alike. Young nobles often come here to pick out and reserve the finest horses for themselves. These horses get sent to Kuronn where they will receive proper warhorse training and bond with their rider.

Near the River Sańni lies Savil, an unassuming mining village. Strong workhorses pull large cartloads of iron to Kuronn for the knighthood, getting to the ore is a tough job however, as some of the veins run beneath the river.
Zanc is a small village next to the river Sańni. Their stables are loaded with the finest workhorses of couronne.
Šancijon

Šancijon was built only recently, but has become a bustling town filled with merchants and travellers. Its original purpose was to guard the eastern side of the road along the coast, but patrols often double up as caravan guards. With recent greenskin incursions and norscan marauders along the coast, caravans enjoy the safety of travelling with a patrol, as long as they stay out of the way.

The people of Juresburh make a living catching fish in the sea of claws, the village itself is very clean and has many shipyards along the coast. The nobles have the village under constant watch as the village is very open to marienburgers, and much of the food the village produces ends up going to the big city somehow.

decades ago, the village stopped paying its taxes, the local lord sent out a small unit of “tax collectors”. expecting a ragtag bunch of rebelling peasants, the knights were horrified at what they saw. The village seemed abandoned, but there was blood everywhere. The leader suspected an orc raid but valuables were left behind, they also would have known if a rumbling orc raid wouldve taken place, orcs not being known for their stealth tactics. At the centre they witnessed a gruelling sight, all the men of the village were piled up, their bodies beaten to pulp, their broken bones sticking out from bruised flesh. The women were never found. investigations ran into dead ends. The only thing that stood out, which was dismissed rather quickly, was that the leader of the unit noticed a thick fog moving towards the south, a fog that almost seemed sentient, and he couldve sworn he saw shapes in the fog. The village was cleansed, the bodies burnt and its history erased. new villagers live here now, unaware of the fate that might await them.
Bošam
Zamak Bryjuann
Kaŭdebiek
South east of castle Brillionne and west of Kuronn castle lies Kaŭdebiek a big lumber jack village.
Zamak Orn

Zamak Orn lies south of castle Kuronn and west of the grey mountains. Its the most southern castle in couronne and it serves mainly as a defensive bulwark against orcs from the grey mountains. Its armed with a lot of trebuchets and archers. its walls are surrounded with mud making it hard for attackers to move.
Brulu is a bridge village west from castle Kuronn. There city is build uppon the bridge working as a defendable position for castle Kuronn when attacked from the west.

Castle Tancred is only recently completed. It sits on a low but steep hill, and the outer wall is studded with towers. The high inner wall allows defenders to turn the region between the walls into a killing zone, whilst the final round keep also has a tall signal and watchtower. The castle has a good well and large stores of food. Fully manned, it could survive a siege for over threemonths. The surrounding land is not particulary fertile, and it is inlikely that a living army could last that long.

Castle Tancred is only recently completed. It sits on a low but steep hill, and the outer wall is studded with towers. The high inner wall allows defenders to turn the region between the walls into a killing zone, whilst the final round keep also has a tall signal and watchtower. The castle has a good well and large stores of food. Fully manned, it could survive a siege for over threemonths. The surrounding land is not particulary fertile, and it is inlikely that a living army could last that long.
Zamak Lonhij

Housing the Great Lighthouse of Bretonnia, also known to the Elves as Tor Alessi, Castle Lonhij sits on the storm-wracked northern coast of the Middle Sea. Castle Lonhij is a lucrative trade hub for all sea trade in the northern hemisphere of the old world, and is very defensible thanks to the high cliffs that encase the dukedoms coast. Currently ruled by Godemar Fitzgodric, head of a Merchant Cabal called the Brethren of the Lighthouse, the city remains under control of the Merchant Cabal rather than Duke Taubert, for the Duke despises the city.

Besides the main Harbor of Castle Lonhij, Brest harvests the most fish in all of the dukedom of Lonhij, providing the city and their neighboring villages with plenty of food. The village is somewhat wealthy compared to most Bretonnian Villages, but not nearly as wealthy as their neighbors, Annumass and Maromm.

Along with its sister village Maromm, Annumass is one of the more wealthy villages in all of Bretonnia. In fact most of its residents are seen as Merchants rather than mere peasants. It is true they still toil day and night working the fields, but behind closed doors, they are inscrutably wealthy compared to the average Bretonnian.

Further inland, past Annumass lies the village of Maromm, a vast village in size compared to most. Maromm boasts the largest vineyards in all of Bretonnia, selling their produce to the markets in Castle Lonhij, where it will be sold and shipped off to far away lands.
Zamak Hrashar

Once a small hunting lodge for the Duke and his vassals, the Lodge has been built into a mighty fortress, encompassed by a moat, and two curtain walls. Currently only garrisoned by a few hundred men-at-arms and a handful of Knights, the fortress could house a great host if there were enough men in Lonhij.

Just off the border of the Forest of Arden and the Dukedom of Artua, Kottevrard produces all the firewood for the Dukedom of Lonhij. Because of its location it is frequently raided by Beastman warbands, but are usually quickly dealt with thanks to the perseverance of Duke Taubert.
Zamak Sierrak

Just north of the village of Sierrak, Castle Sierrak sits on top of a hill, and compared to the village below, is more splendid and pleasing to the eye. The triangular shaped keep has watchtowers at each corner, and is encompassed by a palisade wall except for the stone gatehouse and a short section of wall on opposite sides of the gatehouse.

The small destitute village of Sierrak is very poor when it comes to Lonhij standards. Mainly consisting of small dilapidated mud huts, the villagers work tirelessly to appease their lord and pay his tax. There is a rumor amongst the nobles that a group of Herrimaults use the poor village as a base of operations.
Zamak Sańni
Lu Piui

Settled on an almost volcanic-like hill next to the Sańni River, Lu Piui hosts the start of a small pilgrimage for the Lady, known as “The Field of the Lady of Stars.” Although peasants are forbidden to worship the lady, the villagers often undergo the pilgrimage all the way down to Carcassonne.
Zamak Lioness

Barflor is a village nestled along the central hills of Lioness. The village is known for its tight-knit community and the sagacious leadership of its elder, Liudver. Despite his frail appearance, Liudver commands great respect and authority, his judgments sought by villagers from neighboring settlements for their fairness and ingenuity. The village itself thrives on small-scale trade, with its position in Lioness giving its seasons bustling with activity as traders come in.

Sabli is nestled on the eastern coast of Lioness, surrounded by the serene waters of the Great Ocean. The village is renowned for its vibrant fishing industry, with fleets of boats setting out each day to harvest the bountiful marine life. The villagers of Sabli are skilled fishermen, and their expertise ensures a steady supply of fresh fish to the markets of Lioness.

Sorej is a village known for its diligent shipwrights. The city is a center for artisans and craftsmen, whose works are renowned throughout Bretonnia. The harbor is always busy, with fishermen and shipwrights working tirelessly to support the local economy.

Vuarun is a village renowned for its vineyards and fine wines. Nestled among rolling hills, Voirons annual wine festival attracts connoisseurs from all over Bretonnia, celebrating the villages rich winemaking tradition.

Karekufu is a serene village surrounded by lush meadows and dairy farms. The villagers are renowned for their cheese-making skills, producing high-quality cheeses that are a staple of the northern Lioness economy.
Barlej Mott

Bordering the Dukedom of LAnguille is Barlej Mott, a strategic castle situated on a hilltop that oversees the surrounding northern Lioness hills. The castle serves as a military stronghold and a symbol of protection for the neighboring villages. However, the location is also infamous in Bretonnia for being home to bandits, necromancers, and Chaos cults, with most Lyonens believing the Motte to be cursed despite its strategic importance.
Lu Havr

Lu Havr is the only Lioness port village with naval access to the Sea of Chaos. Vital to maritime trade, the docks are always busy with ships transporting goods to and from distant lands, and the villagers are known for their skills in navigation and commerce.

Zihmarschajm is an outpost of the Empire situated in the Forest of Arden. It serves as a strategic fort, built around a temple dedicated to Sigmar. It is said that upon reaching adulthood, the Imperials of Zihmarschajm have a tradition of venturing towards the Empire for a year to bring back a spouse.

Situated in the western outskirts of the Forest of Arden, Kontrumula is a village known for its fertile fields and agricultural productivity. The villagers grow a variety of fruits and vegetables, supporting the local economy and providing fresh produce to nearby markets.
Ora Łamaj

Ora Łamaj is a small yet formidable castle nestled between Lioness and the ruins of the once-great Mousillon. The castle has seen better days, having fallen into neglect under the rule of Bayard Solon, who governs the lands in the name of the absent King Charles de la Tête dOr III. The castles walls, though not particularly high, are sturdy and well-built, with a single towering black spire that looms ominously over the surrounding landscape. Despite its formidable appearance, the guards of Ora Łamaj have grown complacent in the decade since the last raid. The castles strategic position, far from the sea, has led to a false sense of security among its defenders.
Dźjepp

Dźjepp is an inland village known for its thriving livestock farms. The village is renowned for its production of high-quality wool and dairy products, which are traded in nearby markets. The residents of Dźjepp are skilled farmers and herders, working tirelessly to maintain the prosperity of their community.
Zamak Žyzoru

Zamak Žyzoru sits perched on a ridgeline, just north of where the River Ois flows into the Grismerie. A mile long curtain wall encloses the castle, which consists of two large keeps and many other outbuildings. Duke Hagen is rarely seen in either the castle or the city at his feet as he is normally in Kuronn or on campaign, and so his steward Lord Hincmar lives in one of the two keeps, while the other remains deserted. The city sprawls from the rivers shores to the castles ridge; It is a busy place, filled with more Imperial and Wastelander traders than any other city in Bretonnia, it may in fact be the only place in the world were the name of Maryjenburh does not conjure up images of sea vessels. Much of the city is dominated by streets of fine merchant houses pressed up against horrid tenements and decaying homes, many of which once belonged to fine merchant families. In Žyzoru, it is said that merchant families will only keep their wealth for one generation. As can be expected by its location, the city and castle has been besieged numerous times over its long history, but any knight of the dukedom will be quick to tell you that it has fallen not once due to her valiant knights.
Pjerrułatt

To the north east of Castle Žyzoru; some ways off the main road, is the pastoral village of Pjerrułatt. The land here is not particularly fertile, but its slopes and plains are excellent for shepherds and breeders to raise their flocks and herds.

Right on the road between Castle Žyzoru and Castle Dyflov is the village of Erni. While the people here do make most of their living on raising livestock, its location along the road makes it a prime place as a stop, either in the direction of the Empire or deeper into Bretonnia.

High on the side of the mountain in the Pale Sisters near the headwaters of the River Ois, is the small town of Otmun. There is no permanent residence here for its lord, Duke Hagen, and so any fortifications and buildings here have been wrought by the peasantry over many centuries of inhabitation. The town is the only stop on the trail to the Vale of Florida, and it is from here that many nobles have attempted to sponsor further settlement of the Pale sisters. All of these attempts have failed miserably, either due to the harsh winters or greenskin incursions; and so it has been some time since further settlement has been tried.
Fłoryd

The village of Fłoryd sits in the middle of the Vale of Florida. It is very inaccessible even for a mountainous area. The vales orientation is unique in that it traps sunlight; making the area unusually warm. It only snows during the coldest of winters and flowers bloom here for most of the year. A stream flows off the mountains to the south of the village, irrigating the vale for farming, and dropping in a spectacular waterfall to join the headwaters of the River Sańni below. The soil of the vale in particular seems to nourish a certain flavour in grapes. The flavour is said to be an acquired taste, but many aficionados will travel from far and wide to acquire it.

Halfway up the mountain road to Otmun, and along the upper Ois river sits the mining settlement of Pal. It is one of only three examples of successful Bretonnian settlement of the Pale sisters, the others of course Otmun itself and Fłoryd.
Zamak Ojziljon

Zamak Ojziljon sits on top of a ridge, guarding the road that runs along the foot of the Pale Sisters towards Žyzoru. It is a humble place on the edge of the Forest of Arden and mostly used as a watch over the area for beastmen warherds and greenskin WAAGH!s. Slightly higher up the ridge from the present Castle Ojziljon is a large area of Ruins. The locals say that this is the “Palace Ojziljon,” where one of the old great Bretonnian kings made his court here. While you have never heard of this palace or its king, you are sure there are many things you do not know about.

The Village of Ojzil sits in the valley between the Ojziljon ridge and the Pale Sisters. It is a quiet place, fearful of outsiders and the mountains that they sit at the feet of. One of the very few Bretonnian settlements to survive in these parts of the mountains, it has known the wrath of both vagabonds and greenskins.
Zamak Dyflov

Zamak Dyflov guards the border between the Reik basin and Bretonnia. Directly across the Žyzoru gap from Fort Bierhbres, Castle Dyflov and its lord, Marquis Dyflov, are tasked with guarding against smugglers and nerdowells attempting to enter into or escape from Bretonnia.

Fauesnant is a small community on the road near Castle Dyflov. While most travellers keep moving from Fuenan on to Erni or elsewhere, its location brings the village enough coin to get by, if not rise to wealth.

Betton sits at the foot of the southern Pale Sisters, while most people here lead typical Bretonnian lives tilling the soil, a number of peasants have successfully found valuable metals in the mountains nearby..
Zamak Ard

On the river Grismerie south of Castle Žyzoru is the ancient Castle Ard. Established here long ago to guard the approaches along the river both to and from Mousillon. Today, the castle has been worked into the Cordon Sanitaire as the principal fort in this region.

Cutting timber for use in the city of Žyzoru, the people of Bunmam lead modest lives. While paid for directly by the Duke, timber does not afford much wealth, especially in the face of the various threats facing Bunmam, both those of the nearby swamp and the Forest of Arden.
Zamak Artua

Zamak Artua is a large fortress city, without any villages outside its walls it stands a lone vigil inside the forest of arden. It is the Ducal capital of Artua and Chilfroys main base of operations, but can be mostly found riding out to hunt beastmen. Its large curtained walls hide an imposing keep and a large courtyard, used to provide for the large number of knights and mounted yeomen, because of this, a constant stream of provisions are necessary, and the steady stream of wagons that provide these is almost constant.
Ŭesin

5 years ago this village was like any other, miserable peasants eking out a meagre existence providing for their lord. But that changed when the skaven poisoned their water supply, as the town began to mutate, the skaven attacked. Unfortunately for them, Sir Madregang, who himself began to mutate, beat back the skaven attack. Shortly after, Ŭesin executed those whose minds were twisted and beyond saving, a dark day in their history. The village now acts as a growing haven for the twisted and mutated, which the duke doesnt mind because he barely notices the difference.

one of the few villages with a fortified wall surrounding it. The villagers are proud of its large cathedral dedicated to the lady, but there is more to this than meets the eye, in the back of the cathedral, behind locked doors guarded by hermit knights, rests one of the sacred texts of the lady, which are only allowed to be seen by grail knights. The beastmen can sense the aura of purity it radiates and frequently attack the village. They have thus far been unsuccessful, for the local duke usually rides out to trample them into the mud, and even if the duke doesnt show up, the villagers are well trained in the arts of the bow.
Łarret

Łarret has only recently achieved its status as a city, thanks to recent construction of paved roads, connecting Łarret to major trade routes. Łarret is a decent place to live, where everyone is treated almost equally. The roads are clean, the buildings are well maintained and crime is low. Łarret has its secrets of course, if the town grows too hard, the poor are rounded up and told to leave, those exiled who are found still lingering too close to Łarret are promptly executed, something the inhabitants of Łarret try their best to ignore.

Ambrykurt is an important village between Łarret and the major trade route that Ambrykurt borders. Ever since the construction of the paved road that cuts through the village it has seen an increase in trade caravans. The village provides food and lodging, preparing the caravans for their trip to Łarret.

Lanester is a large commune of farmers and shepherds, surrounded by castle artois in the north east and Łarret in the south west the village is relatively safe from outside threats. Lanester sees a decent bit of traffic, but because of the villages rundown state these rarely stay for long.
Zamak Arras

Zamak Arras was once a beautiful fortress city, but a particularly strong beastmen army rampaged through the south of Artua and laid siege to Arras, many feats of architecture fell to ruin under the rock barrage of the cygors, Ghorgons pummeling everything in their wake to dust and Jabberslythes clumsily crashing into marvellous statues. If not for the then Sir Chlodega the city wouldve been razed completely. Sir Chlodega led a charge deep into the ranks of the beastmen, so forceful was the charge that it toppled even the cygors. The sounds of carnage and death lured out the other beasts that roamed the city, and after an epic battle the knight slaughtered every single one of them. The city, what was left of it, was saved. From the remains of the ruined city the castle was built, and still watches over the southern part of artois.

In ages past the village of Hienham was the site of many battles against greenskins, beastmen and undead. Now its walls are left to ruin, its garrison almost abandoned and the houses are in disrepair. Its chapel however is still as grand as it was when it was first built, and keeps spirits high in the area. The people can fend for themselves and are well fed.
Zamak Lens

In the southern part of the forest of arden lies Zamak Lens, a great bastian amidst a sea of trees. Its strategic position deep in the woods ensures that many tribes of beastmen attack the castle, and inevitably fail. The garrison at castle lens is experienced and self-sufficient, collecting water from nearby streams and hunting game in the woods. At times however it becomes impossible to leave the castle, a particularly great brayherd might lay siege to the castle, so its important the stocks are filled.

The people of Ojssel are always busy tending fields, herding cattle, fishing or hunting game. Every week a squad of knights and yeomen come to the village to escort a cart full of food back to Castle Lens, which in return keeps the village of Ojssel safe, the villagers know how frequent the attacks on the castle are, and therefore double their efforts to make sure the garrison is well fed, if only to save their own skin.
Zamak Biećjun

Zamak Bélthue watches over the eastern part of the forest of arden, the beastmen here are mainly brays, but the garrison is no less undermanned. Sometimes a greenskin incursion makes it through the pale sisters, crushing any beastmen resistance and ploughing through to the west into the lands of man, these are swiftly stopped, experienced woodsmen take potshots at the warbands before retreating back into the woods. When the greenskins reach an open field they are met with lance and blade, and are put to the sword quickly and efficiently.

The villagers of tournon are experienced woodsmen, and often aid in redirecting a greenskin incursion or warherd that stampedes through the woods, the villagers have learned that you dont necessarily need accuracy to beat an opponent, firing off a load of arrows in a general direction from a hidden spot is usually very effective to make the enemy think they are outnumbered and go the other way, usually into a knights lance.

The Fortress city of Munfor, sits at the opposite end of Axe Bite Pass. Encompassed in five tiers of towering stone walls, the Illustrious trade centre is renowned for its fine quality crafts, including Steel weapons and armours, owed to the close association of the Dwarfs of the Grey Mountains.
Žuinar
A small village located near the Bretonnian Entrance to Axe Bite Pass. Žuinar acts as a small trade settlement before encroaching on Munfor.
Chašopje
The hamlet of Hachpied, across the river from Munfor, is a small cattle farm that provides Castle Munfor with a steady supply of Meats and Hides.

Chiae lies at the entrance of axe bite pass and is the first Bretonnia contact coming through the pass. Unfortunately, due to the Empire and Bretonnias constant engagements over axe bite pass, the village of Chiae is littered with graves and corpses.

Sitting north west of Munfor, the City of Pussank rests on the River Grismerie. The markets of Pussank are often flooded with Golden jewellery and crafts, thanks to it neighbouring the gold rich Grey Mountains.
Le Šalem
Huddled on the north side of the Grismerie river, the village of Le Šalem is a small farming village that provides most of its harvest to the city of Pussank.
Siro is a small village that is not very populous, nor flourishing, and that holds a deep clay deposit just off the river bank of the Grismerie river.
In the small woodlands east of Pussank, the hamlet of Ardun provides Pussank with timber for many of the cities construction and outfitting their militias with bows and arrows.
Castle Chimmierl sits on the border of Parravun and Munfor, along the river Grismerie. It is a key defensive choke point into Munfor when approaching from the south.
West of Munfor, the small village of Bjer, provides Castle Munfors supply of mounts for the stables. Although small, Horse breeders are never in short supply in the Horse Duchies of Bretonnia.

The hogs of Itua provide most of its meat and its leather hides to Castle Munfor. The rest is usually reserved for the village itself or as a trade good for any adventurers or other villages needing such goods. Due to the location, Itua has a good relationship with the small village of Łaval in Parravun, and they often trade goods and hold small festivals together.

Le Ukson holds a small knit community of villagers who farm flax for the cities of Munfor. Despite being neither prosperous nor populous, the work they do does not go unnoticed and is often protected from Greenskin raids.

Along a small stream that runs from Axe Bite Pas, and into the Grismerie river, lies the small hamlet of Bul. The residents there work in the small salt mines up into the sides of Axe Bite Pass and into the Grey Mountains.
Hiet Orkal
Neighbouring the Mountains of Massif Orcal, Hiet Orkal sits at its base, ready to pursue any and all greenskin raids coming from the Mountains.
Žyje
Just east of Hiet Orkal lies the hamlet of Giley, a small fishing village sitting on the Grismerie river. The village is not very prosperous due to increasing raids from Greenskins.
Munfor, fertile and rock free soil is in short supply, making Mortu, or rather its soil, critical to abating famine. As a result, Mortuan peasants are thought of as fat and lazy by their fellows.

The city of Parravun, built by the elves long ago, was cut from a lone mountain, Les Monts Seuls, and runs directly along the Grismerie river. Surrounded by deep chasms, it is a key fortress city in holding off any enemies from the Grey Mountains and beyond, from reaching central Bretonnia. Due to the location, many Dwarf families have flocked to Parravun. It is also notable for being the only place in Bretonnia where peasants can live in Stone houses. This is due to a trick of legal language; the homes the peasants carve out of the rock of Les Monts Seuls are considered ‘Caves and thus are not prohibited.
Allobrož

The village of Allobrož is a renowned settlement for its particular horse breeders, even among Paravon which sees use of mainly Pegusi. Allobrož has a fair population and sees many visits by Nobles and Travelers alike.
Žonsiań

Not far from the Grey Mountains lies Žonsiań, a small village with a main focus on Iron mining within the Grey Mountains. Heavily patrolled due to its strategic nature, Žonsiań holds Paravons economy by the pillars.
Near the Grey Lady Pass, Huajard holds a decent size of villagers, and militia alike. Being the first village into Bretonnia from Grey Lady pass, it is quite defensible and strategic in nature.

Found north of the Parravun forest, just north of the Hills of the Dead, and east of Castle Parravun lies Hruner. Its location offers it a decent defensive position at the base of the Grey Mountains, and the Hills of the Dead aids in its defence of the south from attack.
Clemenceau is a village located halfway between Grunere Castle and the Forest of Athel Loren.
The small mining village of Vettar resides due south of the City of Hruner, past the Hills of the Dead. They are destitute and have learned to fend for their own when things get perilous.
La Mizuntal

The small cloister of la Mizuntal abbey is home to a host of Taalite monks. Home to the Holy Wardens of la Mizuntal, these Battle Monks will learn to fight in the ways of war and join Grail Knights on their own quests to collect relics.
Vonćjen
Łaval

In the west of Parravun, near the borders of Munfor, Łaval holds a tight knit relationship with its neighbour, Itua. They often trade goods, such as raw materials for leather and hides. During the Lily Day, the two villages have many weddings and hold a small festival.

Tabane is a small militarised village that houses most of the Militia Guards of Castle Vonćjen. Even though the village focuses on wheat farming, the Villagers, and Guards, will protect their homes with their lives.

Just south west of Castle Paravon lies the village of Lesevre, which hosts large deposits of Wood. Lesevre is very rich in wealth due to Castle Paravon needing coal to fuel the smithies for production of weapons and armour.
Zamak Bastonn

Located in the heart of Bastonne, Zamak Bastonn and the surrounding villages show many indications of their founder, the first king Gilles le Breton, or Gilles the Unifier. Zamak Bastonn itself is almost always a pilgrimage for any Grail Knights, or any who wish to see the testimony of Gilles le Bretons accomplishments.
Sant-Ećjen

Directly east of Bastonne, Sant-Ećjen surveys the eastern border of Bastonne with Munfor. Within the vast verdant fields, the ponies of Bastonne freely breed and openly commune with many Bastonnians. Indeed, they are even smart enough to realize they offer them much protection from the many creatures and monsters of Massif Orcal.
Višy

North of Massif Orcal, the small settlement of Višy endures constant raids from Greenskins and strange rat-like beastmen. Indeed, in the past the village elders were forced to “collaborate” with these strange rat-like beastmen to avoid destruction. They are a hardy breed of peasants and have sustained many traumas.

In the verdant green fields of Uryjak, the peasants there thrive off the trade of many Cattle hides and meats. Indeed whatever is left after the many tithes, Uryjak is able to make very little profit, and mainly survives off of communal farming.

In the north of Bastonne on the Grismerie river, near the Munfor border, the small city of Sud dwells. Being in the Heartlands of Bretonnia, the marketplaces of Sud are often filled to the brim with many goods that come from across Bretonnia. Including even foreign goods from the Empire, and the Wood Elves of the Loren Forest. Due to the nearness of Munfor, relations are straining, and long ago many border wars between the two dukedoms occurred.
Klermon-Fierro is a little fishing village along the Grismerie river that sits across from the Munfor border. The village is fairly small sized due to fish not being a huge export out of the village.
Located in northern Bastonne, Issuar is a predominantly farming community with some small abodes available for passerby adventurers or pilgrims on their way to Zamak Bastonn.
Ćjer

Located at the northernmost point of Bastonne, Ćjer lies on the border of Giseroux. Ćjer is a small trade hub that is visited by many caravans from the dukedom of Giseroux, but has had a harsh bit of bad luck recently due to dreadful Beastmen raids coming from the Arden forest.
Zamak Haramun

Zamak Haramun holds the southern border of Bastonne from the western border of Bordeleaux, and provides a watchful lookout of the forest of Chȃlons and the feet of the mountains of Massif Orcal. The garrison has held off many Greenskin invaders.

Ombier in the past has been raided, pillaged, and razed many times over in the past by Greenskin raiders from Massif Orcal. Calard of Garamont has sent many families to re-inhabit Ombier again, in a vain hope that the village will continue its production of timber from the Chalons Forest.
Zamak Sonhas

Lying just before the borders of Žyzoru, the fortress of Sangasse is a sentinel for any monsters or creatures that wish to venture out from the Arden forest. Indeed, many Beastmen raids have been thwarted by the garrison of knights stationed here.

Behind the defenses of Zamak Sonhas, Kiusse harbors a small salt deposit right off the bank of the Grismerie river. Most of its supply of salt is directed straight to Castle Bastonnes kitchens and warehouses.
Šatel-Hijon

Built inside the old remains of a small castle, Šatel-Hijon is a small farming community that harvests flax from its fields. Due to the location, the fields are vibrant and yield extraordinary amounts of silk. Many inhabitants believe great battles were once fought in the very fields of Šatel-Hijon to bring about its great harvests.
Zamak Ryjom
Łaps

The village of Łaps is home to a hardened group of men and women who have had to fight the dangers of Muziljon for their homes for centuries. Many of Laps inhabitants voluntarily ask for employment under their protector Luca Loup so they can take the fight to the haggard entities that call Muziljon their home.

Directly east of the dread city of Muziljon lies Ard. The hamlet has been targeted for many raids by bandits, highwaymen, and even cultists. Its closeness to Muziljon has always made it easy pickings for the horrors that dwell in the cloudy mists of Muziljon.
Zamak Bordulu

Built upon ancient stonework, the fortress-city of Bordeleaux is perhaps the most important harbour in Bretonnia, rivalled only by Lyon. Zamak Bordulu sits on a cliff which rises above the harbour, looking over the entire sprawling city and nearby sea traffic. It is said that the engines on its walls, and their skilled engineers, are capable of sinking a moored rowboat without damaging the boats to either side. The city is home to two major holy sites in the realm, the First Chapel of Zamak Bordulu, the most sacred Grail Chapel in the kingdom; and the Temple of Manaan, of which some say rivals even the temple in Maryjenburh.
Sant-Žuńja

Right on the coast of the Great Ocean is the village of Saint Junien. Saint Junien was named after a grail knight who long ago defended the peasants in the area from mysterious sea devils. The peasants here continue to rely on Manaan for their livelihood, though many visitors note that they always seem to have one eye out towards the watery horizon.
Sitting on the road between Tureene and Bordeleaux is Ehr. Ehr is an idyllic place, the peasants here seem content most years and grain normally comes in abundance.
The area around Niort is famous for its vineyards. The fruit produced here makes a nice red wine, favoured by many nobles all over Bretonnia.

The peasant town of Ciurenn, though lowly, is nothing to scoff at. The people here live under the protection of the duke and while most make their living in the fields around the town, there are those peasants that have taken up a craft or trade near the town square. Ciurenn is a town dependent on the excesses of Bordeleaux, merchants needing a simple place to stop can often find cheaper rooms and supplies here.

Surrounded by rocky crags, the isolated village of Parthenay sits on a hill overlooking the lands of Bordelen and, across the River Grismerie, Muziljon. The people here haul up salt from the beaches below, pack it, and send it to Ciurenn to their south.
The people of Onhle pride themselves on breeding some of the best riding stock this side of Massif Orcal. Every year, the peasants round up the various herds, and drive them to market in Bordeleaux.

Ruajo lays in a low and wide gulley, sheltered from the winds that constantly blow across the coastal plains of Bordeleaux. The depression also provides some sanctuary from norscan raiders, who often are unable to see it from the ocean.
Ciurrys Vižyło
Dahło
Dahło is a small farming village that provides the nearby temple of Verena with most of its foodstuffs. The fruit grown here is known for its hardiness, and can make a decent vintage.

The fish that come down into the brackish waters of the River Grismerie are known for their size and their taste. Really, many local nobles suppose that is the only reason the peasants continue to dwell in Talons, being far too close to the marshes of cursed Muziljon for their liking.
Zamak Sant Žon-de-Luz

A small castle, established to watch over the farms and woodlands of east Bordelen. It is named after a long dead noble who stopped an orc warboss from Massif Orcal on the grounds where the castle now sits.

In the middle of the rolling plains is the village of Belves. Belves has some of the most.. provincial peasants in Bordeleaux. Their lord rarely comes here, with the yeoman tax collector often being the only visitor to Belves for years at a time.

Sar Saddlebreds are dependable mounts for any knights, yeomen or traveller. The people here pride themselves on producing steads of the highest quality, the result of course is that they only produce a few every season.
Zamak Šatelru

On the edge of the Forest of Châlons sits Castle Šatelru. Châlons is a dangerous and twisted place; dark trees stand over deep ravines, boulders and chasms. One shouldnt be mistaken, it has its beauties; sweet and cool streams, waterfalls and calm pools dot the undergrowth. It is even said that the true sacred lake of the lady lies somewhere within this forest. With this land, comes the typical predations, greenskins, beastmen and far worse make their homes, and so Šatelru stands its watch against incursion.
Munpaźje

Delving into the forest of Châlons for timber, the woodsmen of Munpaźje are some of the bravest peasants in all Bordelen. Their daily task brings them almost constantly into contact with beastmen and other foul monstrosities.

The peasants of Limoj venture into the outlying crags of Massif Orcal, looking for sites for clay pits. While they bring back a good amount of clay, they also tell tales of the things they encounter at the foot of the mountains. The local lord has on more than one occasion deemed fit to send men-at-arms into the foothills. What they fought there remains unknown to most.
Zamak Bryjon

The jewel of Bretonnia, as Brionnians would have you believe, is a remarkable city built out of the local white stone and the high quality sand from its bay, which is one of the things Bryjon is famous for. The city is well defended thanks to its location, lone towers watch over the land that can withstand against entire armies with but a small garrison. The Hall of Minstrels is the most important building in Bryjon, as many would be bards and minstrels hone their skills here. The hall is surrounded by a large garden, which in times of war can be used as a killing room to dispose of invaders. It is a beautiful circular structure made from polished white stone, the inside is home to an auditorium with flawless acoustics, which minstrels use at any time of the day or night.
On the coast of the Great Ocean, the village of Lurd ekes out a meagre existence as a fishing village. Delivering “fresh” fish directly to Castle Bryjon.
The village of Turnefol, the last settlement on the River Brienne before Castle Bryjon. The villagers here take care of great herds of cattle, providing much of the meat needed by the dukedom.

A moderately rich farming village near Bryjon, Bukier acts as a crossroads between the surrounding villages and Bryjon so it sees a decent bit of traffic, thanks to the local toll booth the village is slightly more prosperous than the others, but still just as run down.

Lunel sees many travellers pass by as they live close to the bridge that connects them with Karkasson, be they adventuring knights or merchants. The village therefore is looked after more than others, so passing nobles can at least somewhat bear to look at it.

Gaillac doesnt get many visitors, being so out of the way, yet caravans often leave to deliver crops to Chateau Frontière. Gaillac is one of the biggest food producers of Bryjon.Gaillac, a remote location that often goes unnoticed, being so far away from the main roads. The village is a bustling hub for caravans that transport crops to Chateau Frontière. Gaillac holds a critical role in Brionnes food production.

A somewhat dour village along the northern border, when Castle Gransette was beset by zombies many of those who fled, fled to Mond, dragging several zombies in tow. The attack was repelled, but it left its mark on the village; houses are more rundown and desolate than usual, and the faint stench of death still lingers in the air.
The local nobility is more keen to make visits to Koljur, as they supply most of Bryjon with olives, used for their cuisine. This is why the village is more staunchly protected in times of need.
Zamak Chossehor

Castle Chossehor is more of a giant hospital than a mere fortress. Inside, nobles receive the finest treatments from priestesses of Shallya; while outside peasants beseech the many wisemen and healers that flock to the area. Some complain about receiving their treatment in the open air, but many of the practitioners believe this separation protects their noble clients and disperses the more vile miasmas brought here by the peasants.
The bleating of the herds of local sheep drown out most of the noises during the day, Fua delivers copious amounts of cotton to Castle Chossehor to be used for bandages and cleaning materials.
Kołamje

Nestled in the rolling hills and verdant fields, lies Kołamje, where the air is always fragrant with the aroma of herbs. The village is a picturesque haven with neat rows of herbs that flourish under the warm rays of the sun. The villagers take great pride in their craft, carefully tending to their plants with love and care.
Bižer
